p.s: In the following it will be analysed how Barack Obama uses rhetorical devices to convince the reader/listener that dreams are worth fighting for (l. 25f.).
To begin with he first talks about the EDIT of division in the American country.
He uses the comparison (l. 5f.) ... by geography and ideology; race and religion; wealth and opportunity to show the .
This has the effect of bringing the people to look on there certain aspects and questioning them.

Additionally he then uses various contrasts (l. 9f.) In big cities and small towns; among men and women; young and old; black, white and brown to underline, that every American has the same vision and faith for the future.
This has the effect of uniting the people because of their similarity and also increases the idea of the American Dream.
Apart from that he then talks about his mother and her vision and passion for the same values of America.

To underline the unity between the different people and to eliminate the idea of circumstancial luck he uses an anaphora (l. 19f.) no matter what colour you are, no matter where you're from, no matter how much money you have.

Lastly he uses a climax (l. 24) The steel plant had closed.Jobs are disappearing.In a forgotten corner of America, the American Dream was slipping away to underline the fact that he is needed as a president to turn the life of the Americans to the good.
This also has the effect of showing himself in a better way and make people think up to him.
To put in a nutshell Obama uses a lot of rhetorical devices to convince the listener of a better future with him as a president and trystries to unite the Americans to fight for the American Dream.
